Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The Professional Development and Instruction of Design Comparing both Distance Learning and Face-to-Face Delivery Methods

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Design is a practice (the activity) and a product (the design). The challenge facing educators is the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) requirement to transform the sit in your chair learning environment into working spaces that use technology to support the instructional practices and products of design. Success will be strongly tied to the teachers own self-confidence and self-efficacy in aligning design to their classrooms. Teachers must align content ranging from biology to mathematics to physics.

This collaborative project with the University of Maryland College Park and Morgan State University will immerse teachers from three demographically diverse Maryland school districts in the design process through the use of MyDesign, a mobile application developed through an NSF I-Corps Learning award, which utilizes a growing library of web-based applications to teach and practice design. The teachers will be guided to develop instructional content specific to their classrooms. Developing and testing two PD models across these school districts has the potential to impact the teaching and practice of design. The data and experiences derived from this exploratory and high-risk research could provide timely insights into the comparative strengths and weaknesses between face-to-face and on-line PD for design. Teaching design online utilizing MyDesign has the potential to expand the instruction of design using Massively Open Online Courses (MOOCS) and to personalize the learning of design. The online teaching and practice of design has the potential to engage more women, underserved minorities, those requiring special accommodation, and returning military by providing an anytime, anyplace tool-box to solve relevant problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Maryland's (UMD) and Morgan State University's (MSU) EAGER award continued the development and testing of a Learning Management System for Design, the MyDesign® LMS. The intent was to determine if this LMS could become an "online tool set" and resource for: 1) students and teacher to learn and practice design thinking; 2) the unifrom collection of data across all range of stakeholders regardless of geographic location and disciplinary training; 3) the development, testing and implementation of teacher modified professional development models for design thinking; and 4) the leveraging of online analytical tools to track the teacher use of design thinking within their classrooms.

The EAGER research as laid the foundation for:

1.) The initial development of an online strategy for the professional development of teachers to use and apply the MyDesign® LMS to learn and practice design thinking.

2.) The development of a centralized data collection plan to track student and teachers design efforts framed by the Engineering Design Process Portfolo Scoring Rubric (EDPPSR) developed under prior NSF awards.

3.) The funded E4USA NSF proposal to further develop the MyDesign® LMS concept within the national pilot, 'Engineering for Us All (E4USA)'.

In particular, the outcomes from the EAGER have led, in part, to support the nationally funded NSF E4USA pilot, 'Engineering for Us All (E4USA)', that includes not only the two EAGER universities (UMD and MSU) but also Arizona State University (ASU), Virginia Tech (VA Tech), and Vanderbilt (VU); and a dissemination collaboration with NASA.  

The EAGER research serves as a foundational pillar for E4USA to engage 70 high schools with teachers trained on the design process. The intent of the training is tol empower teachers to develop and integrate design principles and processes into their lesson plans to reach nearly 2,375 students. In summary, E4USA team will apply the EAGER lessons learned and the MyDesign® LMS to: 1) recruit AZ, MD and VA high schools, including teachers and students; 2) co-develop course syllabi, curricula, and assessments for Engineering Design Thinking Principles and Processes; 3) create an "online modality" for the student learning and teacher professional development of the design process; 4) uniformly collect data across all stakeholders; 5) develop, test and implement teacher PD models; 6) leverage online analytical tools; and 7) evaluate approaches for teachers to gain certification for engineering and design in AZ, MD and VA.
